factoid: The conversation turned on the war, on Buonaparte, and on the generals and statesmen of the day.
The old prince seemed convinced that all the men of the day were mere babies who did not know the A B C of war or politics.
The old prince seemed convinced that Buonaparte was an insignificant little Frenchy.
The old prince seemed convinced that Buonaparte was successful only because there were no longer any Potëmkins or Suvórovs to oppose him.
The old prince seemed convinced that there were no political difficulties in Europe and no real war.
The old prince seemed convinced that there was only a puppet show at which the men of the day were playing, pretending to do something real.
Prince Andrew bore his father's ridicule of the new men.
Prince Andrew listened to his father with evident pleasure.
The old prince said that the past always seems good.
The old prince asked whether Suvórov had fallen into a trap set by Moreau from which he did not know how to escape.
The old prince exclaimed "Suvórov!".
The old prince jerked away his plate, which Tíkhon briskly caught.
The old prince considered that Frederick and Suvórov were involved with Moreau.
The old prince said that Moreau would have been a prisoner if Suvórov had had a free hand, but Suvórov had the Hofs-kriegs-wurst-schnapps-Rath on his hands.
The old prince said that it would have puzzled the devil himself.
The old prince said that when you get there you’ll find out what the Hofs-kriegs-wurst-Raths are.
The old prince said that Suvórov couldn’t manage the Hofs-kriegs-wurst-Raths, so what chance has Michael Kutúzov?
The old prince said that Prince Andrew and his generals will not get on against Buonaparte and will have to call in the French so that birds of a feather may fight together.
The old prince said that the German Pahlen had been sent to New York in America to fetch the Frenchman Moreau.
The old prince alluded to the invitation made that year to Moreau to enter the Russian service.
The old prince asked whether the Potëmkins, Suvórovs, and Orlóvs were Germans.
The old prince said that either the lads have all lost their wits or he has outlived his.
The old prince said that Buonaparte has become a great commander among them.
Prince Andrew said that he was only surprised at his father's opinion of Buonaparte.
Prince Andrew said that Buonaparte is a great general.
The old prince cried out Michael Ivánovich.
The old prince said that he had told his father that Buonaparte was a great tactician.
The old prince said that Buonaparte says the same thing.
The old prince laughed.
The old prince said that Buonaparte was born with a silver spoon in his mouth.
The old prince said that Buonaparte has splendid soldiers.
The old prince said that Buonaparte began by attacking Germans.
The old prince said that only idlers have failed to beat the Germans.
The old prince said that since the world began everybody has beaten the Germans.
The old prince said that they beat no one except one another.
The old prince said that Buonaparte made his reputation fighting the Germans.
The old prince began explaining all the blunders that, according to him, Buonaparte had made in his campaigns and in politics.
Prince Andrew made no rejoinder.
Prince Andrew listened, refraining from a reply, and wondered how his father could know and discuss all recent European military and political events.
The old prince concluded that Prince Andrew thinks he is an old man and does not understand the present state of affairs.
The old prince concluded that it troubles him.
The old prince concluded that he does not sleep at night.
The old prince concluded that he wants to know where Buonaparte has shown his skill.
Prince Andrew answered that it would take too long to tell.
The old prince exclaimed that Prince Andrew should go off to his Buonaparte.
The old prince said that Mademoiselle Bourienne is another admirer of that powder‑monkey emperor of his.
The old prince said that he is not a Bonapartist.
The old prince hummed "Dieu sait quand reviendra.".
The old prince quitted the table.
